subject: AI
title: Chunking Tables & Code
description: Special chunking strategies for structured content like tables and code blocks.

hook.text: Your document has a pricing table. The chunker splits it after row 3. The retrieved chunk says 'Enterprise plan: $â€”' because the price was in the next chunk.

buildup.text: Tables, code blocks, and lists are fundamentally different from prose. Splitting them mid-structure destroys their meaning. Standard chunkers treat them as regular text and break them apart.

discovery.text: Detect structured elements first: use regex or HTML/Markdown parsing to identify tables, code fences, and lists. Keep them as atomic units â€” never split inside a table or code block.

twist.text: Sometimes a table exceeds your chunk size limit. Convert it to natural language ('The Enterprise plan costs $499/month and includes...') or split by rows with repeated headers.

climax.text: A chunking pipeline should have element-aware splitting: prose gets recursive splitting, tables stay whole, code blocks stay whole, and oversized elements get special handling.

punchline.text: Not all text is paragraphs. Chunk tables and code as the structured data they are.

quiz.question: Why do tables need special chunking treatment in RAG?
options: Tables are always too small to chunk
Splitting mid-table destroys the relationship between rows and columns
Standard chunkers already handle tables perfectly
